title: Energy Secretary Ed Miliband recruits Extinction Rebellion cheerleaders to government roles to help push through costly agenda
body:
Ed Miliband has recruited three Extinction Rebellion cheerleaders to government roles to help him push through his costly green agenda.

The Energy Secretary has quietly appointed the advisers who have all publicly expressed admiration for the radical action group which has repeatedly brought chaos to Britain's streets.

Mr Miliband's top team includes former Extinction Rebellion (XR) lawyer Tobias Garnett who led a successful court challenge against the Metropolitan Police five years ago when it tried to ban the group from staging disruptive protests in London.

At the time, Mr Garnett said the world was in the midst of a 'mass extinction' event, adding: 'We are responsible – and there is a limited amount of time to do something about it.'

Mr Garnett, now a special adviser to Mr Miliband, has since removed references to his XR past from his LinkedIn page.

He is joined at the Department of Energy by special adviser Eleanor Salter, a writer and activist who previously praised XR's 'hugely successful' campaign of disruption, saying it had been 'a great accelerator for activism'.

In the past, Ms Salter has called for a crackdown on aviation, including an end to all domestic flights.

She urged the last government to ban all new road building and suggested many cars should be taken 'off the road altogether'.

Energy Secretary Ed Miliband has quietly recruited three cheerleaders to his Department of Energy who will help him push through the costly green agenda

Part of Mr Miliband's team is former Extinction Rebellion (XR) lawyer Tobias Garnett who led a successful court challenge against the Met Police five years ago when it tried to ban the group from staging disruptive protests in London

Also joining the team is writer and activist Eleanor Salter, who previously praised XR's 'hugely successful' campaign of disruption, saying it had been 'a great accelerator for activism'

In September, Mr Miliband also recruited academic Rachel Kyte as the UK's new special representative for climate, working jointly with the Foreign Office.

Ms Kyte previously sported an XR badge at a major international climate summit and praised an eco-activist who had glued herself to the pavement outside Shell's headquarters in London.

She also appeared to back XR ahead of a week of international civil disobedience, saying people should 'act now or get out of the way'.

But former Tory leader Sir Iain Duncan Smith said: 'The cost of what [Ed Miliband] is proposing is already astronomic.

The fact he has surrounded himself with some of the most extreme advocates of Net Zero is alarming and it is the public that will pay the price.

'I also find it extraordinary that the Government should appoint people whose view of the way to get things done is to endorse the tactics of anarchy.'

Mr Miliband also recruited academic Rachel Kyte as the UK's new special representative for climate, who previously sported an XR badge at a major international climate summit

Mr Miliband's bid to make Britain a 'clean energy superpower' by 2030 is at the centre of the Government's agenda and seen as central to the goal of decarbonising all sectors of the economy by 2050.

The Climate Change Committee estimates that hitting the goal will cost the UK one to two per cent of GDP per year. By 2050, the annual cost could be £50billion.

But it can be revealed that one of Mr Miliband's junior ministers has previously predicted the bill could be twice as high.

In 2019, Miatta Fahnbulleh, then chief executive at the New Economics Foundation, said meeting the 2050 target would require 'a huge level of government investment'.

'We think it needs to be much higher, probably three to four per cent of GDP,' she said.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly mentions "Miatta Fahnbulleh, then chief executive at the New Economics Foundation" in the sentence: "In 2019, Miatta Fahnbulleh, then chief executive at the New Economics Foundation, said meeting the 2050 target would require 'a huge level of government investment'." This confirms the target entity is present in the text.
reasoning.statement_detection: The same sentence attributes a direct statement to her: "'We think it needs to be much higher, probably three to four per cent of GDP,' she said." Thus, the entity is making a declarative statement about climate policy.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q48699931 lists her occupation as economist and politician, and includes a position held as chief executive officer (though the organization is unspecified). The description matches the article’s reference to her role at the New Economics Foundation. Candidate Q47538978 is a singer/activist with no relevant occupation or position, making it an implausible match. Therefore Q48699931 is the best candidate.
reasoning.authority_verification: As chief executive of the New Economics Foundation—a prominent economic think‑tank—Q48699931 has the appropriate authority to comment on national climate targets and investment levels. The statement aligns with the kind of policy analysis the foundation is known for.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible that the former chief executive of a UK-based economic think‑tank would publicly discuss the fiscal requirements of the 2050 net‑zero target. The quote’s content and tone are consistent with her professional background.
reasoning.final_justification: The entity is present, making a statement, and the candidate Q48699931 matches all critical identification and authority criteria. No other candidate fits the description or context. Therefore, the correct Wikidata ID for the entity referenced in the article is Q48699931.
